material.mattext: Both Raymond (Rain Man) and Prot (K-PAX) present diagnostic challenges. According to Matthews (2005), why might clinicians rationally disagree about unusual presentations?
Psychiatric diagnosis is purely subjective
Clinicians are randomly distributed in diagnostic tendencies
Given ambiguous evidence, different prior beliefs (base rate expectations) lead to different rational conclusions - "weird" presentations challenge standard diagnostic inference
Only one diagnosis can ever be correct

Correct!

Matthews' analysis of "rational inference from weird evidence" shows that prior beliefs (base rates) affect diagnostic conclusions. Clinicians with different priors can reach different conclusions, both rationally. For Prot: if your prior for "aliens exist" is zero, you conclude delusion; if non-zero, you might entertain alternatives. For unusual presentations, there's often no "obviously correct" answer - rational people can disagree because they weight evidence differently.

The correct answer is C.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Diagnosis involves subjective judgment but isn't arbitrary; there are rational constraints.
  • B: Disagreement reflects prior beliefs and evidence weighting, not randomness.
  • D: For ambiguous cases, "correct" may be underdetermined by available evidence.

Raymond's savant abilities are genuine; Prot's claimed alien origin may or may not be delusional. According to Vrij et al. (2019), what makes distinguishing delusion from reality so difficult in Prot's case?
Aliens might actually exist
Behavioral cues cannot distinguish between sincere belief (delusion) and deliberate deception - and genuine delusion produces no "deception" cues at all
Psychiatrists lack training in alien detection
Prot deliberately obscures diagnostic cues

Correct!

Vrij et al.'s research shows deception detection relies on cues that are "faint and unreliable." But Prot's situation is even more complex: if he genuinely BELIEVES he's from K-PAX (delusion), he's not deceiving at all - he's sincere. Sincere delusion produces no deception cues because there's no deception. You can't detect "lies" in someone who believes what they're saying. The behavioral cues that might indicate deception simply don't appear.

The correct answer is B.

  • D: If Prot is delusional, he's not deliberately obscuring anything.
Both films explore how "different" minds relate to "normal" society. According to Pratto et al. (1994), how might social dominance orientation predict attitudes toward both Raymond and Prot?
High SDO would predict acceptance of difference
SDO is irrelevant to attitudes about neurodiversity
High SDO correlates with preference for hierarchy; unusual minds may be seen as threats to social order or as requiring institutionalization rather than accommodation
Low SDO individuals reject all difference

Correct!

Pratto et al. show that high SDO correlates with preference for established hierarchies and skepticism of those who don't fit. Both Raymond and Prot challenge normal social order - Raymond through autism, Prot through claimed alien status. High SDO orientation would predict seeing these individuals as problems to be managed (institutionalized) rather than accommodated. Low SDO would predict more acceptance of difference.

The correct answer is C.

  • A: Opposite: high SDO correlates with hierarchy preference and skepticism of difference.
  • B: SDO predicts attitudes toward many social groups including disabled individuals.
  • D: Low SDO generally predicts more acceptance of diversity.
Dr. Powell (K-PAX) becomes personally invested in Prot's case. According to research on emotion differentiation (Kashdan et al., 2015), what risk does this personal investment create?
Investment always improves clinical judgment
Personal feelings have no effect on diagnosis
Undifferentiated emotional investment may impair objective assessment; distinguishing professional concern from personal fascination requires high emotion differentiation
Only detached clinicians make accurate diagnoses

Correct!

Kashdan et al.'s research on differentiation applies to clinicians: a clinician must distinguish between professional interest (appropriate), fascination with an unusual case (potentially distorting), rescue fantasy (countertransference), and intellectual excitement (could bias toward preferred explanation). Dr. Powell's investment creates risk because these distinct emotions might blend into undifferentiated "interest in Prot" that distorts judgment.

The correct answer is C.

Dr. Powell's investment creates risk because these distinct emotions might blend into undifferentiated "interest in Prot" that distorts judgment.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Investment can bias as well as motivate; it's not uniformly positive.
  • B: Emotions clearly affect judgment; claiming no effect is naive.
  • D: Some investment is necessary for engagement; the issue is differentiated investment.

Charlie transforms from exploiting Raymond to genuinely caring for him. According to McKnight & Kashdan (2009), this transformation illustrates which characteristic of purpose as a "self-organizing system"?
Purpose is externally imposed by circumstances
Purpose creates conditions that sustain and strengthen itself - Charlie's initial positive experiences with Raymond generated further investment that became self-perpetuating
Purpose develops independently of experience
Purpose cannot emerge from selfish beginnings

Correct!

McKnight & Kashdan describe purpose as self-organizing - it creates conditions that sustain itself. Charlie's transformation shows this: initial positive moments with Raymond (the casino, shared jokes, physical affection) generated further investment. Each positive experience created motivation for more engagement, which created more positive experiences. Purpose didn't appear suddenly; it organized itself gradually through accumulating experiences.

The correct answer is B.
